ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: I really enjoyed this class. I did not come from an economics background so the material was sometimes a challenge to understand in comparison to the other students who were economics majors. At first I thought that the reading responses were a waste of time but grew to actually enjoy them because they made me focus on the information in the reading that Prof. Sindelar wanted us to take away. As a whole Sindelar was a very well-prepared lecturer and had a vast array of knowledge. I almost wish she focused more and what she has done in the past rather than other studies that she didn't know as thoroughly. Student presentations were not exactly the best use of time in devoting 3 classes to not well-prepared presentations were not exactly optimal.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Jody Sindelar  Prof. Sindelar was great! She is so responsive to emails and really wants the students to learn as much as they can. Overall, she is the perfect instructor for the course.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: The course is a behavioral economics course that focuses on the economics behind alcohol, illicit and licit drugs, obesity, and smoking. Behavioral economics is not completely steeped in economics, so its a merge of psychological factors as well as economic factors.
